evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline (hist_t0_prelim).
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified coordination failure is resistant to alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, and these factors sufficiently explain the breakdown in communication among ground crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues, consistent with the observed coordination failure.

slot_statements.availability: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation, indicating availability of personnel to perform the required stop at the TRP.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No evidence suggests that external factors or system errors prevented the tug instructor from stopping at the TRP, indicating the deviation is resistant to common defeaters.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation fits key features of the incident, including failure to stop at the TRP and continuation of pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline (hist_t0_prelim).

assumptions: The lack of explicit mention of effective stop warnings implies their absence
Continued movement beyond TRP despite cues indicates failure to challenge or alert
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged before TRP exceedance
If hardware or environmental factors were primary causes rather than coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H4 show the trainee requested stop and the aircraft passed the TRP without effective stop challenge, supporting the presence of coordination failure as per R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on exact communication timing and content between crew and ground

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues, consistent with the observed coordination failure.

assumptions: Assuming that the absence of explicit mention of timely challenge or stop warnings in the evidence implies they did not occur effectively.
Assuming that the TRP markings were present and visible as no evidence suggests otherwise.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored, or if marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show divergent assumptions and lack of effective challenge or stop warnings during pushback; H4 confirms the aircraft exceeded the TRP despite cues, supporting the communication breakdown root cause over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the completeness of communication details and absence of explicit challenge warnings in the evidence.

node.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation, indicating availability of personnel to perform the required stop at the TRP.

assumptions: Presence and active control by the tug instructor implies availability to perform the required stop
No evidence of communication breakdown or mechanical failure affecting instructor control
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor was absent or not in control during pushback
If environment or marking deficiencies were severe enough to explain missing the TRP
If mechanical control failures were verified and caused the pushback to continue

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 directly indicate the tug instructor was present and actively controlling the pushback, supporting availability of personnel to perform the required stop at the TRP. This contradicts alternative explanations involving environment or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states the instructor performed the stop at TRP; only presence and control during pushback are confirmed.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe, confirming its availability as a factor.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data, supporting its relevance to the incident.

node.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe, confirming its availability as a factor.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were not visible or inadequately placed during the timeframe, or if crew attention to the TRP was confirmed absent due to marking issues, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft reached the TRP markings but continued moving beyond it, indicating the TRP was present and observable, which contradicts the claim that the marking deficiency was the primary factor. This supports the alternative R1 (procedural deviation) over R3 (marking deficiency).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The procedural deviation fits key features of the incident, including failure to stop at the TRP and continuation of pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

defeaters: If evidence showed a mechanical failure or braking fault causing uncontrolled movement beyond TRP
If evidence showed the TRP stop state was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor
If evidence showed inadequate TRP visibility or marking causing the miss without procedural lapse

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the nosewheel reached the TRP but pushback continued beyond it until blast-fence contact, matching the procedural deviation key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The identified coordination failure is resistant to alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, and these factors sufficiently explain the breakdown in communication among ground crew.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The coordination failure explanation sufficiently accounts for the observed events.
defeaters: If fault codes, tests, or repeat malfunctions indicated mechanical control failure, this would favor R4 and challenge the coordination failure explanation.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and role changes but the aircraft still passed the TRP without effective stop warnings or shared understanding, supporting the coordination failure explanation (R2) over mechanical failure (R4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure is present; ambiguity remains if unseen hardware issues contributed.

node.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data, supporting its relevance to the incident.

assumptions: The inadequacy of TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement is inferred from the aircraft passing the TRP despite the engine at idle and no other mechanical failure evidence provided.
No direct evidence of mechanical control failure is present in the provided evidence items.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, adequate TRP markings that were visible and prominent, or if mechanical control failure evidence was stronger and more directly linked to the incident, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly describes the aircraft passing the TRP marking and continuing beyond it, supporting the claim that the TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate and relevant to the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by preliminary historical data and diagnostics.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, supported by multiple independent tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences that rule out alternative explanations in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affected stopping, consistent with observed symptoms and corroborated by tests and repeat failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by preliminary historical data and diagnostics.

defeaters: Presence of fault codes, diagnostics, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical or control-system failure
Direct evidence of hardware malfunction or control/braking system issues during the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe human actions, communication, and procedural events with no mention of mechanical or control-system failures, fault codes, diagnostics, or repeat malfunctions supporting R4. The aircraft passed the TRP and continued moving, indicating procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: No evidence suggests that external factors or system errors prevented the tug instructor from stopping at the TRP, indicating the deviation is resistant to common defeaters.

assumptions: The instructor’s attention and control as described imply no unnoticed system errors or external factors prevented stopping at TRP.
No evidence of environmental or marking deficiencies sufficient to explain the deviation without instructor lapse.
defeaters: If evidence showed inadequate TRP visibility or marking (supporting R3), or communication failures about the TRP stop state (supporting R2), or mechanical control failures (supporting R4), this would challenge defeater resistance.

quotes.exact_quote: The instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H3 shows the instructor was actively controlling and attentive during pushback, and H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP and continued moving without stopping, indicating no external or system factors prevented stopping, supporting defeater resistance.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly excludes all external factors; assumptions rely on observed instructor attention and lack of reported system errors.

node.statement: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim context.

assumptions: TRP marking visibility and placement were inadequate enough to explain the miss absent attention lapse.
No other mechanical or communication failures caused the miss.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew recognized TRP and expected stopping but continued moving due to procedural deviation, this would favor R1.
If TRP markings were clearly visible and adequate, undermining the marking deficiency claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking despite engine idle, supporting that TRP marking deficiency materially enabled the miss, favoring R3 over R1.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence on crew recognition or attention state; ambiguity in whether procedural deviation contributed.

No evidence in the packet indicates communication or procedural deviations as primary causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug or aircraft controls were functioning normally or if communication or procedural errors were clearly documented as primary causes, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

node.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, supported by multiple independent tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences that rule out alternative explanations in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP at engine idle implies a mechanical/control failure rather than procedural or communication errors
No contradictory evidence from communication or procedural deviations is present in the provided history

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H3 shows the instructor was actively controlling and attentive during pushback, and H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP and continued moving without stopping, indicating no external or system factors prevented stopping, supporting defeater resistance.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly excludes all external factors; assumptions rely on observed instructor attention and lack of reported system errors.

defeaters: If evidence showed a mechanical failure or braking fault causing uncontrolled movement beyond TRP
If evidence showed the TRP stop state was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor
If evidence showed inadequate TRP visibility or marking causing the miss without procedural lapse
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the nosewheel reached the TRP but pushback continued beyond it until blast-fence contact, matching the procedural deviation key features.

assumptions: The lack of explicit mention of effective stop warnings implies their absence
Continued movement beyond TRP despite cues indicates failure to challenge or alert
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and acknowledged before TRP exceedance
If hardware or environmental factors were primary causes rather than coordination failure
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H4 show the trainee requested stop and the aircraft passed the TRP without effective stop challenge, supporting the presence of coordination failure as per R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
availability.uncertainty_source: limited detail on exact communication timing and content between crew and ground

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The coordination failure explanation sufficiently accounts for the observed events.
defeaters: If fault codes, tests, or repeat malfunctions indicated mechanical control failure, this would favor R4 and challenge the coordination failure explanation.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and role changes but the aircraft still passed the TRP without effective stop warnings or shared understanding, supporting the coordination failure explanation (R2) over mechanical failure (R4).
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure is present; ambiguity remains if unseen hardware issues contributed.

assumptions: Assuming that the absence of explicit mention of timely challenge or stop warnings in the evidence implies they did not occur effectively.
Assuming that the TRP markings were present and visible as no evidence suggests otherwise.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored, or if marking deficiencies were proven to be the primary cause, this would change the assessment.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2 and H3 show divergent assumptions and lack of effective challenge or stop warnings during pushback; H4 confirms the aircraft exceeded the TRP despite cues, supporting the communication breakdown root cause over marking deficiency.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the completeness of communication details and absence of explicit challenge warnings in the evidence.

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were not visible or inadequately placed during the timeframe, or if crew attention to the TRP was confirmed absent due to marking issues, the conclusion might change.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft reached the TRP markings but continued moving beyond it, indicating the TRP was present and observable, which contradicts the claim that the marking deficiency was the primary factor. This supports the alternative R1 (procedural deviation) over R3 (marking deficiency).

assumptions: TRP marking visibility and placement were inadequate enough to explain the miss absent attention lapse.
No other mechanical or communication failures caused the miss.
defeaters: If evidence showed crew recognized TRP and expected stopping but continued moving due to procedural deviation, this would favor R1.
If TRP markings were clearly visible and adequate, undermining the marking deficiency claim.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking despite engine idle, supporting that TRP marking deficiency materially enabled the miss, favoring R3 over R1.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit evidence on crew recognition or attention state; ambiguity in whether procedural deviation contributed.

assumptions: The inadequacy of TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement is inferred from the aircraft passing the TRP despite the engine at idle and no other mechanical failure evidence provided.
No direct evidence of mechanical control failure is present in the provided evidence items.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, adequate TRP markings that were visible and prominent, or if mechanical control failure evidence was stronger and more directly linked to the incident, the conclusion might change.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly describes the aircraft passing the TRP marking and continuing beyond it, supporting the claim that the TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate and relevant to the incident.

defeaters: Presence of fault codes, diagnostics, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical or control-system failure
Direct evidence of hardware malfunction or control/braking system issues during the incident
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe human actions, communication, and procedural events with no mention of mechanical or control-system failures, fault codes, diagnostics, or repeat malfunctions supporting R4. The aircraft passed the TRP and continued moving, indicating procedural or communication issues rather than mechanical failure.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP at engine idle implies a mechanical/control failure rather than procedural or communication errors
No contradictory evidence from communication or procedural deviations is present in the provided history
defeaters: If evidence showed no verified braking/control faults or repeatable failure signatures
If communication or coordination failures with no hardware evidence were documented
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly supports mechanical/control failure by showing the aircraft continued moving beyond the TRP despite engine idle, consistent with control malfunction and ruling out communication failure.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond the TRP with engine at idle implies a mechanical or control system failure affecting stopping.
No evidence in the packet indicates communication or procedural deviations as primary causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug or aircraft controls were functioning normally or if communication or procedural errors were clearly documented as primary causes, this would change the assessment.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft continued moving beyond the TRP despite engine idle, indicating a control/braking malfunction affecting stopping, which supports R4 over alternatives per discriminator texts.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit test or diagnostic results confirming mechanical failure; reliance on observed symptoms only

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:availab.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation, indicating availability of personnel to perform the required stop at the TRP.
The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation
The pushback movement continued beyond the TRP stop/release point until contact with the blast-fence occurred
The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and physically reachable during the pushback
The active tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:defeate.statement: No evidence suggests that external factors or system errors prevented the tug instructor from stopping at the TRP, indicating the deviation is resistant to common defeaters.

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:fit_to_.statement: The procedural deviation fits key features of the incident, including failure to stop at the TRP and continuation of pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge and alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline (hist_t0_prelim).

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability:.statement: Ground crew were alert and attentive, capable of perceiving and responding to cues in a timely manner
Communication devices (radios, intercoms) used by ground crew were operational and accessible
Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary for coordination
Ground crew members were physically present and on duty during the critical time period

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:defeater_resi.statement: The identified coordination failure is resistant to alternative explanations, as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, and these factors sufficiently explain the breakdown in communication among ground crew.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:fit_to_key_fe.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions held by crew about stop-state or intent, and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues, consistent with the observed coordination failure.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:ava.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe, confirming its availability as a factor.
The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operating conditions
The TRP marking was sufficiently prominent in size, color, and contrast to be noticed by the flight crew
The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss by reducing crew awareness or recognition of the TRP
The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:def.statement: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim context.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:fit.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data, supporting its relevance to the incident.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:availabili.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure was present and detectable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by preliminary historical data and diagnostics.
No external factors prevented the mechanical or control systems from being available
The braking system was functional and accessible during the event
The tug or aircraft control system was operational and available at the time of the incident

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:defeater_r.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, supported by multiple independent tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences that rule out alternative explanations in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:fit_to_key.statement: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affected stopping, consistent with observed symptoms and corroborated by tests and repeat failures in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.
